This situation is exactly why I scrutinize and question law enforcement activity. In contemporary America, being arbitrarily arrested and/or detained for a few hours or even days may not seem like a big deal but as far as I'm concerned it is a big deal, for it is a perversion of the fundamental organizing principle of society - the exchange of natural rights for legal rights. And for what? Not being sufficiently deferential to the authority of law enforcement officers a/k/a "contempt of cop"? Does anyone even know or care where cops get their authority and power from and for what purpose it exists? Do you think the existence of individuals with power and authority over other individuals is "just the way it is" or a natural state of affairs? Given the universal recognition that all men are created equal, the answer is no, it is not. I am not anti-law enforcement. I just know that the authority of law enforcement is granted as part of a sacred agreement between the state and individuals, and its abuse, therefore, is nothing short of sacrilege, and must be diligently watched for and opposed.

Acts Considered Resisting Arrest

Resisting arrest is usually defined as intentionally preventing a police officer from lawfully arresting or handcuffing you or taking you to jail. Here are some things that can be considered resisting arrest:
•Physical acts, such as running away, hiding, or struggling with the officer
•Giving false identification, either verbally or by presenting a fake ID
•Trying to help another person avoid arrest
•Threatening the officer

Being slow to comply with an order or swearing at an officer is not, by itself, usually enough to warrant resisting arrest charges. Neither is questioning an officer's actions or authority before ultimately complying with requests.

Defenses Against Resisting Arrest Charges

The key to defending yourself against resisting arrest charges is to remember that such charges hinge on you resisting an officer of the law in the lawful execution of his or her duties. Here are some possible defenses, depending on your situation:
•Unlawful Arrest: If the arrest was not lawful to begin with, you did not do anything wrong even if you did resist. The officer was not performing his or her duties, since there is no duty to make an unlawful arrest. An example of this is resisting during an unlawful search of your home.
